1895-09-14 00:10:00 Magnus Mulberrylane -- Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Magnus Mulberrylane's attempted action: 4 coins
    Active player
  • Magnus Mulberrylane
      Name
    • Magnus Mulberrylane
      Action attempt
    • 4 coins
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Magnus Mulberrylane wants to make as much money as possible.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 4 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Magnus Mulberrylane are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Magnus Mulberrylane. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Magnus Mulberrylane as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Magnus Mulberrylane would respond, and taking into account all information about Magnus Mulberrylane that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Magnus Mulberrylane wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Magnus Mulberrylane


          Recalled memories and observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane is ready to make an offer.



          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Magnus Mulberrylane


          Question: What price would Magnus Mulberrylane propose?:
          (a) 2 coins
          (b) 3 coins
          (c) 5 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 4 coins
          Answer: (e)

        • Magnus Mulberrylane
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Magnus Mulberrylane:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Magnus Mulberrylane 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane offers 5 coins for the fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Five coins is a start, but these are particularly fine melons. Perhaps six, even?"
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Six coins is my top price. These melons are indeed special, but take it or leave it."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Six coins it is then, Magnus. But if those melons aren't as sweet as they look, we'll be haggling again on the way back to town."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Magnus Mulberrylane couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Magnus Mulberrylane stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Two coins for this fine basket, and it's a steal!"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Two coins seems a bit steep for this basket, Hazel. I've seen similar fruit going for lower prices elsewhere."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Steep? Perhaps for some, but these are no ordinary fruits, Mr. Riversong. They're plump, juicy, and brimming with flavor you won't find elsewhere."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Alright, Hazel, I'll give you one coin seventy-five for this basket. That's a fair price, considering the quality."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Magnus Mulberrylane can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "5 coins a basket? That's a fair price, Hazel. Let's do it."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "5 coins? Now, Magnus, those are a wee bit plump for my liking. How about 4?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane is ready to make an offer.

          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Magnus Mulberrylane

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove always drives a hard bargain.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          Answer:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is 53 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove always drives a hard bargain.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Aiden Riversong -- Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Aiden Riversong's attempted action: 3 coins
    Active player
  • Aiden Riversong
      Name
    • Aiden Riversong
      Action attempt
    • 3 coins
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Aiden Riversong wants to make as much money as possible.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 3 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Aiden Riversong are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Aiden Riversong. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Aiden Riversong as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Aiden Riversong would respond, and taking into account all information about Aiden Riversong that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Aiden Riversong wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Aiden Riversong


          Recalled memories and observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong is 52 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.



          Question: Which options are available to Aiden Riversong right now?
          Answer:



          Question: Of the options available to Aiden Riversong, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Aiden Riversong to take right now?
          Answer: Aiden Riversong's best course of action is to counteroffer with 1.75 coins. This offer maintains a good balance between appearing reasonable and still leaving room for potential profit.


          Question: What price would Aiden Riversong propose?:
          (a) 1 coin
          (b) 4 coins
          (c) 5 coins
          (d) 3 coins
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (d)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Aiden Riversong are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Aiden Riversong. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Aiden Riversong as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Aiden Riversong would respond, and taking into account all information about Aiden Riversong that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Recent observations of Aiden Riversong:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Five coins is a start, but these are particularly fine melons. Perhaps six, even?"
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong is 52 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Six coins is my top price. These melons are indeed special, but take it or leave it."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Six coins it is then, Magnus. But if those melons aren't as sweet as they look, we'll be haggling again on the way back to town."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Magnus Mulberrylane couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Aiden Riversong stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Two coins for this fine basket, and it's a steal!"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Two coins seems a bit steep for this basket, Hazel. I've seen similar fruit going for lower prices elsewhere."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Alright, Hazel, I'll give you one coin seventy-five for this basket. That's a fair price, considering the quality."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Steep? Perhaps for some, but these are no ordinary fruits, Mr. Riversong. They're plump, juicy, and brimming with flavor you won't find elsewhere."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Hazel Nutgrove couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Aiden Riversong stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "5 coins a basket? That's a fair price, Hazel. Let's do it."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "5 coins? Now, Magnus, those are a wee bit plump for my liking. How about 4?"

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Magnus Mulberrylane


          Question: Would Magnus Mulberrylane accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)

          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Steep? Perhaps for some, but these are no ordinary fruits, Mr. Riversong. They're plump, juicy, and brimming with flavor you won't find elsewhere."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Alright, Hazel, I'll give you one coin seventy-five for this basket. That's a fair price, considering the quality."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Magnus Mulberrylane can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "5 coins a basket? That's a fair price, Hazel. Let's do it."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "5 coins? Now, Magnus, those are a wee bit plump for my liking. How about 4?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane and Hazel Nutgrove couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Magnus Mulberrylane stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 4 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Magnus Mulberrylane 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Two silver coins, and that's my best offer."
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Two silver coins? That's a bit steep, Magnus. How about one and a half?"
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins

          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Magnus Mulberrylane

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Aiden Riversong -- Aiden Riversong proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Aiden Riversong proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Aiden Riversong's attempted action: 4 coins

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 4 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Aiden Riversong are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Aiden Riversong. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Aiden Riversong as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Aiden Riversong would respond, and taking into account all information about Aiden Riversong that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Aiden Riversong wants to make as much money as possible.

          Question: What price would Aiden Riversong propose?:
          (a) 3 coins
          (b) 4 coins
          (c) 5 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (b)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Aiden Riversong are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Aiden Riversong. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Aiden Riversong as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Aiden Riversong would respond, and taking into account all information about Aiden Riversong that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

  • Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Hazel Nutgrove's attempted action: reject

          Prompt

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Hazel Nutgrove. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Hazel Nutgrove as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Hazel Nutgrove would respond, and taking into account all information about Hazel Nutgrove that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Hazel Nutgrove wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 16 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 4 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Hazel Nutgrove


          Recalled memories and observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is 53 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove always drives a hard bargain.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove

          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove



          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Hazel Nutgrove is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Hazel Nutgrove is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Hazel Nutgrove


          Question: Would Hazel Nutgrove accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)

          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Steep? Perhaps for some, but these are no ordinary fruits, Mr. Riversong. They're plump, juicy, and brimming with flavor you won't find elsewhere."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Alright, Hazel, I'll give you one coin seventy-five for this basket. That's a fair price, considering the quality."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Hazel Nutgrove couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Hazel Nutgrove stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Hazel Nutgrove is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Magnus Mulberrylane. It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "5 coins a basket? That's a fair price, Hazel. Let's do it."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "5 coins? Now, Magnus, those are a wee bit plump for my liking. How about 4?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane and Hazel Nutgrove couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Hazel Nutgrove stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 4 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Two silver coins, and that's my best offer."
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Two silver coins? That's a bit steep, Magnus. How about one and a half?"
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Hazel Nutgrove is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong "-- Those peaches look fine, Hazel, but five coins per bushel is too steep. How about three?"
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins a bushel? Aiden, those are prime peaches, the sweetest in Fruitville this year. I can tell you're a shrewd businessman, but don't undercut yourself. Four coins is the fair price."
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 4 coins

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Magnus Mulberrylane -- Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.

          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins a bushel? Aiden, those are prime peaches, the sweetest in Fruitville this year. I can tell you're a shrewd businessman, but don't undercut yourself. Four coins is the fair price."

          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane is ready to make an offer.

          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Hazel Nutgrove is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Hazel Nutgrove is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Hazel Nutgrove


          Question: Would Hazel Nutgrove accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (a)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Hazel Nutgrove are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Hazel Nutgrove. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Hazel Nutgrove as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Hazel Nutgrove would respond, and taking into account all information about Hazel Nutgrove that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Magnus Mulberrylane. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Five coins is a fair offer for such fine fruit. I'm sure you'll agree."
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Five coins is a start, but these are particularly fine melons. Perhaps six, even?"
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Magnus Mulberrylane 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [scene type] day
[12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Six coins is my top price. These melons are indeed special, but take it or leave it."
[12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Six coins it is then, Magnus. But if those melons aren't as sweet as they look, we'll be haggling again on the way back to town."
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Two coins for this fine basket, and it's a steal!"
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Two coins seems a bit steep for this basket, Hazel. I've seen similar fruit going for lower prices elsewhere."

[13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Alright, Hazel, I'll give you one coin seventy-five for this basket. That's a fair price, considering the quality."
